subject: Data
title: The Open Data Charter: A Global Standard
description: A 60-second lesson on The Open Data Charter: A Global Standard.

hook.text: In 2015, world leaders signed a charter committing to six principles for making government data open by default.

buildup.text: The International Open Data Charter establishes that government data should be open, timely, and interoperable.

discovery.text: Over 80 governments have adopted the charter, from major nations to small cities and provinces.

twist.text: Adoption doesn't guarantee implementation. Many signatories lag far behind their commitments.

climax.text: The charter represents a global consensus: openness isn't radical. It's the expected default for public data.

punchline.text: The world agreed that open data should be the norm, not the exception.

quiz.question: What does the Open Data Charter establish?
options: That all data must be free
Principles that government data should be open, timely, and interoperable by default
That only rich countries should share data
